author: Gandalf1
title: "A wizard is never late, Frodo Baggins."
review:
I picked up this set at the LEGO Store, and I am very pleased with it, though there are a few minor complaints. Here's why:

Box

The box was a little bit hard to open without totally ripping it, but this isn't a new thing. It was very well designed, and had an ad for a LEGO The Lord of the Rings video game.

Instructions

The instructions were good and easy to follow, however, for some reason, they never actually tell you to build the minifigures. You just start off with the cart, and once it's finished, it shows Gandalf and Frodo  in their spots already assembled. There is also an ad for LEGO The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey sets.

Parts

The parts were good. Some of the interesting ones (to me) are a red Ninjago snake, a yellow 4-stud long wand/rod, a brown book, a wax-sealed letter, a carrot (both parts), largish wagon wheels, and last but most :), the horse. Actually I think it's technically a pony, but whatever. It's a very good new piece, it can balance even while rearing up, and it's just a good update.

Minifigures

Frodo Baggins
Frodo has the nice new hobbit-hair element in dark brown, a double-sided head, a sand-green shirt with suspenders (or isn't it braces for you Brits? ;D), and short dark-brown pants, with no hobbit feet, though I don't care much about that. The head has a sort of cheerful, peaceful look on one side, and a worried, something's wrong face on the other side.
Gandalf the Grey
The mysterious wizard has a grey, non-printed standard wizard hat, a grey, non-printed standard wizard cloak, :D a grey, non-printed newly molded wizard beard, and grey, non-printed standard wizard pants. The grey, not-quite-standard wizard torso is printed on both front and back, but these printings are almost useless when Gandalf has his beard and cloak on! Oh, and the head. It's not double sided, because really, what would change? He has bushy eyebrows, and even a mouth and everything, but you don't see it unless he shaves.

The Build

The build was not difficult, but there were parts where you feel like you kind of had to figure part of it out for yourself, and that the instructions didn't quite explain it correctly. It uses hinge-pieces to achieve the sloping sides to the cart, and on the horse, a 1x2 brown brick with a 1x2 plate on top fill the cavity in the horse's back.

The Completed Model

The model is neat to look at, and you just have to roll it along and re-enact the scene from the movie. :-)

Summary

A good set, but not quite worth the money. Of course you should buy it anyway, but it seems that they took sets that were worth $9.99, and decided to bring up the price to $10.99, and it still seems like $10. Then they bring it up to $11.99, and then $12.99 where it is now. But aside from the slightly sneaky price-raising on these small sets, this is a good set, and if you want Gandalf, you've gotta get this set. If you want a happy face for Frodo, you'll get that too. Pretty much, if you get only two LEGO Lord of the Rings sets, get this one. If you get only one, make it Shelob Attacks. :D

author: Almaras
title: A disturber of the peace...
review:
This is a great starter set! There is no conflict, but it works well to reflect the beginning of the Fellowship of the Ring. The box is the only one that isn’t dark and gloomy; its background is a setting sun over green fields, which is brilliant because it makes it stand out straight away, despite its small size.

Okay, so now for the build. I pleased to find that one of the most exciting additions to this set wasn’t in a bag. The horse was just floating loose in the box, which was great because it meant I could get straight into making it rear up and show off to the other, now somewhat boring, horses nearby. I was surprised to find more resistance than I was expecting when moving the horses’ back legs. There is a slight ‘click’ that you feel more than hear when the horse is fully upright, but the resistance is good because, if your horse is on a baseplate, you can have it only rearing up a little. However, without the baseplate the horse can’t balance unless it is either all the way down or all the way up, which is a little unfortunate, but still a massive improvement. The rest of the horse is better as well: it has a longer, swishier tail; a more rounded head and neck, and improved detailing on its face, which will no longer support the armour for regular horses.

The cart itself. The cart was an interesting build, with some techniques that were new to me (such as the pillars on the four corners for the sides). Given that it’s only 83 pieces it didn’t take very long, but I didn’t rush. When it’s finished, it’s a little frustrating for a perfectionist like me that Gandalf cannot sit perfectly centred, he has to sit to one side, which I am finding very annoying. The back of the cart looks a little empty, so I will be raiding my non-TLotR sets for awesome accessories so that the other minifigs can envy Gandalf! I think filling the cart more will also help to stop the one problem I have with it: The contents of the cart rattles around too much. Even though I was carrying it as though it were made of glass, I still had to reset all of the fireworks (they had fallen from the barrel), go back to find the carrot (which had fallen out altogether), and remove the backpack to get to the letter that was stuck between the pack and the barrel. Needless to say, that cart won’t be moving from my shelf for at least 20 minutes, until I want to pick it up and examine every detail again.

But now for the best feature of all: The Minifigures. Okay, so you get a happy and carefree Frodo Baggins, which is a nice change. He is wearing a simple green shirt (which reveals a little of his chubbiness – something I love about all of the Hobbit minifigs!) and braces, adding to the laidback feel of the Shire set. Frodo also has a sad, worried face, which reminded me of our puppy. And you also get Gandalf the Grey, the disturber of the peace, complete with his fireworks! Gandalf is, obviously, all in grey. He has detailing on both the front and back of his torso (as does Frodo), although you can see very little of it after his cloak and awesome new beard block it. I would have liked the beard to come up a little more, on the sides and especially on the back, because it is the only hair he has. I know it would get in the way if you wanted to give the beard to a minifig with a hair piece, but Gandalf does look a little strange with just his hair and hat. And, sadly, he only has a single sided head, but I guess this is fair as you only see his eyes anyway.

Well, that’s Gandalf Arrives. For a small set it has a lot going for it. If you’re still not sure, just get it, even if you end up raiding it for parts (thankfully there is no flick-fire missile defences to prevent this!). Think about it this way: If you want the entire Fellowship, you need this set or you will never have a Gandalf to annoy your other minifigs by not letting them pass!

author: Sebastian
title: Don't look a gift horse in the mouth.
review:
I wish this proverb would apply to this set as it it heavily overpriced for what you get. This is also the case with some of the other sets in the line but it's really evident here because of the small size. The cart is neat with its dark tan pieces that might reflect the gloomy atmosphere of the plot. The only gripe I have with the design is that they should have used a hinged 2x2 turntable plate so you could steer the cart around. The star in this, of course, is the new horse which was the main incentive for me to get the set. It's even better than I thought and has easily become my favourite moulded piece. The figures are good, too, though they are not the best the line has to offer. Gandalf with his hat is just your ordinary castle wizard, very similar to the one in 5614. I like Frodo a little better because he spurts exactly the two facial expressions (happy/sad) his movie actor Elijah Wood is so (in)famous for. 

Inspite of the high price, this is still the perfect starter set for the line and for castle fans the great horse should make it really worth buying.

author: Cult_Of_Skaro
title: "A wizard is never late, Frodo Baggins. He arrives precisely when he means to."
review:
This set recreates the opening scene of Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring where Gandalf drives into Hobbiton to  celebrate Bilbo's birthday. This is the smallest of the LotR sets, and is only an excuse to give us a Gandalf minifigure. However, that does not make it any less a fun set.

Box

The box is small, though it really could have been smaller. On the front, it is decorated with a simple image of Gandalf and Frodo and the cart (inexplicably superimposed over a picture of the Shire at sunset). The back is unusual, in that it does not show any play functions, but not surprising, as there are none. As evidence of LEGO's recent 'green' policy, there is some sort of badge on one of the flaps saying that the box was made out of recycled paper. Another thing that I assume is a recent trend is that on one side, the theme is printed trilinguallly. It says:

LEGO: The Lord of the Rings
LEGO: Le Seigneur des Anneaux
LEGO: El Señor de los Anillos\

This interested me, because normally, even a international set has its name in English. The set name too is written in two other languages.

L'arrivée de Gandalf
La Llegada de Gandalf

 Instructions

Nothing to speak of. The booklet has the same artwork on the front as the box. I found no mistakes. After the building section, there is a parts inventory, followed by an advertisement for 9473, the Mines of Moria. After these, there is a checklist showcasing all the LotR minifigs. Instead of just showing one of each minifig, it shows any minifigs who appear in multiple sets the number of times they appear. This is clever on LEGO's part, as it gives the feeling of getting new minifigs every time, even if it's really just a rerun.

Parts

These are surprisingly interesting. There are a lot of bits in Dark Tan, a carrot, some large wagon wheels, and best of all, a new articulated horse. This set is really worth buying multiples of for the sole purpose of the horse. I'm actually considering getting another one so I can mount my Rohirrim soldier from 9471.

Minifigures

There are two, both really fantastic. They are:

Gandalf the Grey

This is the minifig that makes this set a necessity, as it recreates Gandalf's look from the beginning until Moria. He has several new/recolored parts; an updated beard, a Dark Bley cape, and a Dark Bley Wizard hat. However, there is one problem. Gandalf does not have a double-sided head, which means he cannot appear angry, which could be a problem if you're trying to recreate the Balrog scene. I found a solution to this, however. Sir Ian McKellen has two minifigures, Gandalf and Magneto. Magneto's head works very well to give Gandalf that sense of righteous anger.

Frodo Baggins

This is totally different from the Frodo minifigures in 9472 and 9470. It is the Shire version of Frodo, as opposed to the other one, which I think of as the "Ring" version. This is a very nice minifigure. His torso is Sand Green with buttons and suspenders printed on it. His head is entirely different from that of the other version, and has a happy face on one side and a sad face on the other. He has one new piece, the Hobbit hairpiece, which I hope will be used elsewhere in future years.

The build

This is not very interesting, but not unexpectedly so, due to the price tag. I'd like to think its got a more interesting one than other sets of the same price point, such as Catwoman Catcycle City Chase, though I admit I actually don't own the latter.

The completed model

This is really quite pleasing, considering. The cart certainly looks nice, and makes the Hobbit look small in comparison. The one problem I found is that it's impossible to stick Frodo next to Gandalf on the cart. This was rather dissapointiong, and I wish the designers had thought of this, as it would've greatly improved the set IMO.

Summary

If you're a LotR fan, buy it. It's the only way you're going to get Gandalf. If you're a Castle fan, buy it. The cart will look great in a medieval layout. If you like rare parts, this has several uniquely colored ones. If you're a Space fan...Forget about it. Thanks for reading.

-LEGOlas1

author: tkettle9719
title: "An odd-looking wagon with odd-looking packages rolled into Hobbiton..."- J.R.R. Tolkien, "The Lord of the Rings"
review:
The above line, from the first chapter of the first part of "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring", basically explains what happens in the scene depicted in the set. Out comes Gandalf, bringing his magically amazing fireworks into the town, along with his horse and wagon. Here, he meets with Frodo, and they converse. It's a beautiful, memorable scene, and is a great, happy introduction to the Lord of the Rings line of sets. It's also the only light set, which makes it very unique. All I can say is that it's amazing. 

Pros

  • -Lego has once again created a wonderful line of figures and creatures; Gandalf (the Grey) is very awesome and grey, and is exclusive to this set, Frodo is smiling in a luscious green Shire suit, and the new horse has really gone advanced; it can act terrified and raise up!
  • -The tan and sand-brown parts really make an excellent wagon upon which Gandalf can sit; it's a simple start to a great line.
  • -All of the little details which fill in Gandalf's cart are also really wonderful; a carrot to feed your now adjustable horse, fireworks in a basket, etc...

Cons

  • -Say you're moving the cart throughout your MOC Shire, and you're reenacting a LOTR intro. As you move the cart, it's very possible that the fireworks will fall out of the barrel. As Mad-Eye Moody, Gandalf's brother's (Albus') friend, would say, "CONSTANT VIGILANCE!"
  • -I'm also not a fan of the 1x2 with one stud tile in the cart where the Grey sits; I know that it's probably there to show that the wagon is bumpy, but I want him in the middle. 
  • -I know that this is really minor and doesn't really matter, but I wish that the pieces which create the whole angle for the wagon are maybe a bit too gray. Making them in brown would make the cart look much better to me. 

While no set can be perfect, I think that this is about as perfect as you can get with this set idea. I think that it's a great representation of the whole "Lord of the Rings" line in general, and serves as a great introduction to a line that can end up being really awesome. If you buy a set from the "LOTR" this year, make it this!

author: 00cheese
title: Gandalf the great
review:
In my opinion this set is great. But sadly there is no place for Frodo to sit down next to Gandalf. Otherwise this is a great set and it is worth the price!

P.S this is my first review

author: Hylocera
title: You're late!
review:
To be honest, LEGO's interpretation of the classic opening to the Lord of the Rings is both disappointing yet satisfying. Let's go into a more detailed review of this set.

The Building Experience

There really wasn't much of an "experience", which isn't unusual for a set of this size. Some interesting techn

iques were introduced, though, like the angled sides of the wagon.

The Parts

Lego really did a great job including some interesting parts in this set, like the book, Ninjago snake, and the figs. I also really enjoyed playing around with the new horse, which is both molded better than earlier versions and is also more posable, due to having jointed hind legs like previous versions had jointed necks. The use of the snake was really good (I'm assuming it's the huge dragon firework that Merry & Pippin set off), and there were some unusual pieces I had not possessed before, like the dark tan bag thing and the carrot. My only issue with the parts is that the book had no "cover printing", but that is a minor issue.

Playability

I personally created a small forest vignette to recreate Frodo running down the hills to meet Gandalf, but by itself, the set has close to zero playability. You can make Frodo read the book, and make Gandalf feed his horse a carrot, but the wagon itself is awkward to move around and there's not much you can do with it besides moving it around awkwardly. They could've at least added a small tree or some other sort of scenery to make the scene more interesting. The wagon is also a bit large (I believe it's taller than Gandalf even when he's wearing his hat), but it's simple and easy to modify and is packed full of great fireworks, etc.

Value for Money

It's honestly probably overkill to write such a long review for such a small set, so if you're just looking for summaries, this is the section for you. The value for money, in my opinion, is the most important part of this set, because, as I stated earlier, there's not much to do with this set other than take it apart and use its great parts in other creations. As a "to-be-scrapped" set, it was worth the money, with it's unique color scheme, versatile minifigs, and awesome horse, although I believe a bit of foliage could've been included without a raise in price.

Conclusion

Overall, this is a great set. It disappoints me because it's more recognizable as a generic LEGO wagon than what it is actually named (Gandalf Arrives), but since I tear all my sets apart anyway it satisfies me with it's great variety of parts. 4/5 Overall, thanks for reading! I hope this review is helpful.

author: Shistavanen_brick
title: The wizard pays a visit, Baggins is excited...initially.....
review:
LEGO Lotr sets have finally hit the shelves in Sweden. I just bought this a couple of days ago and as soon as I saw the box in my hand I got transferred back to 2001 & the fond memories after watching the first film in the series. Just how cool is it that LEGO has given us sets from these movies? I can't wait to see what the future holds in store for us fans...

Minifigures.

It's hard not to like these guys. LEGO has put a lot of heart in these plastic representations of both Gandalf and Frodo. Here's a "closer look":

Gandalf. He is new as a figure though parts are certainly taken from both the Castle and Harry Potter line, only altered in colour. What I like is the torso printing along with the grey overall look. It looks very wizardry. You can't go wrong with that pointy hat and the wand/staff. His face is somewhat hidden in his huge beard but the face itself is very cool, not double-sided. On the other hand, he shouldn't have to - being a wizard it might be better to be stern whether you are happy or angry. Game-face.

Frodo. I believe this one might be a bit unusual, a possible collectable? Here we have the Shire Frodo, before everything starts to become one major turmoil, quite different from the quiet, calm hobbit life. Frodo has a double-sided face, I think they have captured the emotions quite well. Frodo seems to sway from happiness to light despair. The green shirt with suspenders looks good. The hair is spot on hobbit hairstyle.


Horse & cart.

This brown horse is just grand in so many ways. The colours and the printing is great. Way cooler is the fact that it is able to prance. That feature is new and will be useful for brick-filmers and display action. The cart included is very fun to build. It is much more sturdy than many carts from other themes from a different year (for instance Mill Village Attack). Smart design and has a bit of a rugged feel to it. It also comes with quite a lot of things, fireworks, a book, a carrot among other things. The wheels also roll as they should. It almost becomes as an obsession for me to just give it a swift roll, if the set is too close to my desk. I guess that means that LEGO did a good job with the set?


Summary thoughts.

I like this set a lot. Could be that I'm a bit bias, as with LEGO Star Wars, but I really believe this is a very good set. Partly because of what it represents to me as a fan of the theme (the books, poems, songs, the movies and legacy of what Tolkien created), but also for the great possibilities the parts and/or the figures have if you want to create something from your imagination. The only downside could be with the price, though I KNOW it's a licensed theme, so it probably needs to be a bit more pricier. This is the first slice we have from the Shire, so I won't be picky about details.


Pros:
  • It's a real LOTR set. No MOC.
  • You get 2 great minifigures. 
  • You get cool horse.
  • You get a sturdy, well-filled cart.

Cons:
  • I was going to go for the price-point, but I decided not to be picky.

author: CapnRex101
title: 9469 - Gandalf Arrives
review:
This is the smallest set of the Lord of the Rings theme so far (excluding polybags) and is actually a very nice little model in my opinion. It includes two excellent Minifigures, both of which are exclusive to this set, although this Frodo figure also appears in a polybag, but I do not really count that one as the polybag is unreleased in the UK at the time of writing. There are some lovely pieces included in the set and is an accurate recreation of a charming scene as it appears in Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring film. 

Box/Instructions

The image on the small box is fantastic in my opinion. It features the moment that Gandalf draws up in to Hobbiton on his cart as Frodo greets him which is well recreated in Lego here. The background shows a tranquil countryside scene with the sun setting far off in the distance and some long grass in the foreground which is very realistic indeed. Along the top of the box cover is the Lego Lord of the Rings logo and a shot of the One Ring of Power on Sauron's finger with a faint map of Middle Earth visible behind it. On the back of the box are several images of different aspects of the set, as there are really no features. There is also a small advertisement for the upcoming Lego Lord of the Rings game and in the background is some more of the map of Middle Earth.

The instructions share the same image on the cover as the box and I found no mistakes in the instructions and no missing pieces. In the back of the booklet is a gallery of all of the Lord of the Rings Minifigures released in this first wave of sets and there is an advertisement for set 9473, The Mines of Moria as well.

Parts

There are lots of excellent parts in this set as I mentioned above. These include one of the brand new horses which I think are superb, a relatively large amount of dark tan and tan for such a small set, and two large cart wheels which are very useful I find. We also get a brown book, a carrot (which is fairly rare), a red Ninjago snake, which only comes in one other set, and a brown barrel. These accessories are quite extraordinary given the size and cost of the model and there are two lovely new hair piece moulds. Gandalf has a brand new beard (so a sort of hair piece) and Frodo has an incredibly accurate dark brown piece for his somewhat unique hair style. All in all, an amazing selection of parts!

Minifigures

There are two Minifigures included, the first of which is Frodo Baggins. This figure is exclusive, but for a polybag, as in this set he is wearing the casual clothes he does in the movie unlike the other sets with Frodo included. I will begin at the top with the new hair piece which is seen on all of the three Frodo figures and is a brilliant piece in my opinion as it perfectly recreates the style from the movie. It is cast in dark brown with lots of texture and I absolutely love it. The head piece too is outstanding, it is printed with two expressions which is always nice, the first of which has brown eyebrows and a cheerful expression which really does resemble Elijah Wood in the film. On the other side is a slightly concerned expression with the same brown eyebrows as the alternative face. 

His torso is printed just like his outfit in the film and is predominantly sand green which looks fantastic. The collar of his green buttoned shirt is open and he is wearing brown braces and a nice studded belt. There are lots of creases in the garment which adds a bit more realism to the appearance of the figure. The back is also printed with his braces crossing over, the rest of his belt, and some more folds in the fabric of the shirt. The arms are sand green like the torso and his hands are flesh coloured. Being a Hobbit, Frodo does of course have short legs, which are brown like the trousers he wears in this scene. One accessory is included for him, and that is the book he is seen reading in the film as Gandalf arrives in his cart. The book piece can be opened and closed, but can only be held by the figure in the open position.

The other Minifigure included is the legendary wizard, Gandalf the Grey. This figure is totally exclusive to this set which makes it a little more special and is extremely accurate to his movie appearance as one would hope. He wears a large dark grey wizard's hat which is not a new mould, appearing previously in Harry Potter and Castle sets among others, but never before in dark grey. A buckle is moulded in to the piece and there are some folds in the hat, which look lovely. It would be nice to have some printing on the buckle to make it stand out a little more, but the component still looks awesome. His head is printed on just the one side with a smile, cheek definition, some wrinkles around his eyes, and very bushy eyebrows. I can completely understand the piece only being printed on one side as the reverse is not covered unlike on the Frodo Baggins figure. The brand new light grey beard part is excellent with plenty of moulded texture and an accurate look to that of Gandalf so it suits him very nicely. I hope to see this beard used again in the future. Gandalf also wears a dark grey cape which matches the rest of his outfit.

His torso is printed with his crease ridden grey robe, a rope crossing his chest, and a brown belt with a silver buckle. This design looks marvellous but is in fact mostly obscured by his long beard. The back too is printed with the rest of his creased robe, the rope crossing his chest and the belt, which is also covered up, this time by the cape. The arms are grey and his hands are flesh coloured. His legs too are plain grey with no printing which looks fine as there is not really anything of note seen on Gandalf's legs in the film anyway. He carries his staff which is formed by a brown stick piece, simple, but it does the job well and short of making yet another new piece, this is as good as it gets I think.

The build

Being a small set, the build is very short, only about ten minutes, but actually features some fun construction techniques. The way in which the sides of the cart are attached is quite clever and the shape has been achieved very well indeed. The back panel of the vehicle too is attached using clips which works really nicely. That is really about it, but given the size of the set, this is not bad at all and I enjoyed it.

The completed model

The model is really wonderful in my opinion and I am delighted with it overall. The brand new horse which pulls the cart is brown and is printed with white patches of hair on its face. Black reins are visible on the head of the animal as are the eyes of course. This new horse can now not only move its head, but also rear up on its hind legs which is very nice indeed. The legs are moulded in to a cantering position which is more realistic than the old static looking horse. 

The cart is attached to the horse using a grey horse hitching and at the front of the cart is a place for Gandalf to sit, slightly offset to the right of the vehicle. Behind this seating area is the main storage area of the cart which has a dark tan bag and a barrel in it. In the barrel are three fireworks, including a red snake which is intended to be the dragon firework set off by Merry and Pippin during Bilbo Baggins' birthday party, for which Gandalf has come to Hobbiton. A carrot is found back here along with an envelope which is found in the bag. I believe this is the envelope in which Gandalf places the One Ring of Power for safe keeping. The cart rests on two large wheels which look absolutely brilliant.

Summary

This is an excellent set for the price and is a must have for any Lord of the Rings fan as it includes one important member of the Fellowship of the Ring, Gandalf the Grey, who is exclusive to this model and is a key character of course. This Frodo figure too is lovely and is exclusive to this set (other than the currently uncommon polybag). The cart itself is very nice indeed and the accessories are extraordinary. However the playability of the set may be a little low for younger children as there are no features as such, nor is there any conflict in this scene, so I am going to dock a point for that as there may be other sets which appeal more to this age group.


Overall - 9/10

author: Mr_Malfoy
title: "A wizard is never late, Frodo Baggins. Nor is he early. He arrives precisely when he means to."
review:
After seeing several licensed themes come and go, I have decided that The Lord of the Rings/The Hobbit theme is the best licensed theme since LEGO Star Wars hit the shelves way back in 1999. This is the smallest set from The Lord of the Rings theme (minus the polybags and the key chains). This set is perfect for an introduction of the LotR theme, due to the fact that it includes two main characters: Gandalf the Grey and Frodo Baggins. Even at $13 dollars, this set is worth every penny. Read on to find out why.

MINIFIGURES:

1. Frodo Baggins - In this set, Frodo is dressed in his Shire outift, and has not undergone the journey to destory the One Ring. The likeness to actor Elijah Wood is uncanny. He's wearing a light green buttoned shirt with brown overalls. His face has two sides: smiling and scared. The new Hobbit hair is perfect. His accessory is a book, true to the movie (despite the fact that the book is comically large when compared to him).

2. Gandalf the Grey - Fantastic. In this set, he wears his grey robes, which don't have a lot of detail (which is okay, since his torso is covered up by his cape and beard). He wears a dark grey cape and a dark grey hat, and carries his staff with him (admittedly, it would've been nice if his staff resembled the one from the trilogy).

PARTS - This set includes a nice selection of parts: a brown book, the Ninjago snake in red, a letter, a carrot, a wizard hat, Hobbit hair, the brilliantly designed new horse, and some fireworks. A good amount of part for a smaller set.

BUILD - A quick, enjoyable build, with a couple of surprising techniques along the way.

FINISHED MODEL -  Lovely to look at, well-designed, and yes: do give into temptation and roll the cart along.

SUMMARY - An excellent set, a perfect introduction to the LotR theme, two important characters, a beautiful model, and a new horse to boot, all for $13! This set also goes along well with 79003 An Unexpected Gathering. My verdict -

10/10

BUY THIS SET

author: Bricky_Bricko_Brick_997
title: An Excellent Re-creation
review:
This set is a remarkable achievement for LEGO LOTR! As my first review, I hope to please!

Just so you know when considering my review, I AM a LOTR fan, as of two weeks ago!

Pros

  • Pro 1 The Horse's newly-gifted posability is great!
  • Pro 2 The Cart is spaceous and has a good choice of items within it!
  • Pro 3 The minifigures are very special and deserve a great big thumbs up!

Cons

  • Not one Big Criticism! Good job, LEGO! 

HOWEVER, just make sure you get some other sets along with this - AT THIS VERY MOMENT I am experiencing playtime with this set on it's own. Let's just say it'll be better soon, along with some Orcs or Uruk-Hai...

Overall, this is a great set and is worth the price!

 

I Would Recommend This To A Friend!

author: Matroxide
title: Not Late nor Early
review: Frodo, reading his book, hears a cart in the distance.  Shutting the book, he rushes over to the source, Gandalf the Grey.  "You are late." Frodo greets his friend. Gandalf replies "A wizard is never late, nor is he early. He arives precicely when he means to." Gandalf then smiles as Frodo hops from the ledge into the cart and hugs the wizard. The set is small, yet fun as it has one of the greatest characters in LOTR, Gandalf. The possabilities are endless on what you can do with the set, like Gandalf gives Frodo a ride to Mordor and uses the fireworks to destroy Saurons Tower, but it all depends on how far from cannon you want to go. I was disapointed that the set did not come with the Ring, but other than that I loved the set and recomend it highly. The set also features a new, posable horse that can veer on its hind legs. The build is short and simple, and is a great starter set for newer Lego fans!

author: redspam
title: "A wizard is never late, nor is he early, he arrives precisely when he means to." - Gandalf
review:
"A wizard is never late, nor is he early, he arrives precisely when he means to." - Gandalf

Gandalf is here! Put on a magical show using his fireworks! I must say, the better part is the minifigures. But over-priced.

Minifigs

Exclusive.
Gandalf - Exclusive, after all, he isthe greatest wizard of Middle-Earth!
Frodo, (Shire) - Exclusive version of Frodo.

Vehicles

Wagon with the latest version of a Lego horse.

Features

The horse's hind legs are posable. er, you can open the book. Exciting.

Etc.

Cool fireworks.
FEED DA WABBIT FWOOD TO DA HORS-EEEE.

author: Super_Mario_64
title: Gandalf! You're Right on Time!
review:
I recently purchased this set from a Walmart for 13 dollars, same as lego price. As I will explain, this is a tremendous set for only 13 bucks.             

 Pros

  • The minifigs. they look great and they come with fantastic accesories.
  • The wagon. It is a very nice build and very spacious and comes with alot of stuff to put in it.
  • The Horse.The horse is a new Lego horse, so it's legs and head/neck can pivot up and down. I also have a fourth pro to this set and it is the box.Its a GLOSSY box and the design is good  as well.

Cons

I have no cons about this set!

  • Con 2
  • …

This is a great set for only 13 dollars I would have payed 15 for it. I would recommend this set to any LOTR fan.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Gandalf and Shire Frodo
review:
Set #9469 Gandalf Arrives: In 2012 when this first hit retailers shelves this was the only method for owning a Gandalf the Grey Mini-Figure, to complete your Fellowship you had to buy this set. It was also the only set to feature Shire Frodo until the Polybag arrived. Now... Gandalf has become the most common Mini-Figure appearing across both LotR and Hobbit Themes in over 10 sets, one of which is quite impressive in scale and look. So is this set a necessary set for your collection?

Read on and find out.

Box/Instructions

Being a 14.99$ set (when it originally arrived) this set's box is pretty standard for that size range and price. It shows off the set, the back shows a few minor play features of the set (none of them gimmics) and that's it. The design might be simple, but it's pretty nice overall.

The instructions are also standard, considering the size of the model is it any surprise to find this is only 23 pages long? It has easy to follow directions for building, a Mini-Figure checklist for 2012 LotR sets (Except the Polybags) and that's all there is to say really.

Parts

To be honest I don't think this set has any rare or unique parts, it just has standard pieces. I stand corrected, there is the new Robber Backpack piece seen in LEGO City sets, if you don't particularly care for LEGO City and aren't collecting it this will be your first time picking one of these up and they do look very nice.

You also get a red snake piece from Ninjago, which is a unique color for the piece I do believe. It wasn't common at any rate, here it's meant to be the large firework that Gandalf made in the film for Bilbo's party.

Minifigures

Gandalf the Grey, there's really nothing new to say about him. He's the same version we've come to expect in LEGO form from the LotR Theme and The Hobbit. He's got the same accessories as every other Gandalf, the cape, his staff, the only thing missing is Glamdring since this is before he had it in the films.

Shire Frodo is the same version from the Cooking Corner Polybag with the same printing, and a book.

Honestly they aren't bad Mini-Figures, the trouble is LEGO made them so readily available since their initial plans involving the Fellowship being split up between all the sets of 2012 that they aren't really that impressive. For a set this size they are also uninspiring, I honestly would have preferred seeing at least one other Hobbit in this set, preferably one we didn't get in any of the other sets, an older Bilbo perhaps or Sam's girlfriend. Sure they don't match up with the Scene the set is aiming to re-capture, but since when has that ever stopped LEGO from providing good Mini-Figures? If some license themes can have 4, once even 5 Mini-Figures included in sets this small what changed to make that so difficult for other Themes?

The build

The cart in this set is a fun build, it more than makes up for the lackluster Mini-Figures and really, it's one of the main reasons why I still bought it. (Aside from my Completist nature.)

Building the sides of the cart is a real treat, and the opening back section is great as a play feature.

The completed model

The finished model features as close an interpretation in LEGO form as you're ever going to see for that Cart Gandalf rode in on, it might not be as large, but it does serve its purpose well. My one complaint would be the means Gandalf sits on it, because this makes it impossible not to bend or wreck his cape when he is sitting on the cart.

If the model had worked around this feature to accomodate it, as The Wizard Battle managed to do for Saruman it would score a bit higher mark. As it stands, if not for the new Horse piece and the interesting looking firework accessories this model might not get as high a rating as it does.

Summary

Overall, unless you're aiming to purchase the entire run of LEGO's Lord of the Rings you can definitely skip this set. While it does include a new horse piece, a few interesting accessories and a great looking model I'm afraid the fact that the Mini-Figures in it are so easy to come by after the fact that buying it at this late stage of your LotR collecting would be rather pointless.

Especially seeing as how most stores have it rarely in stock and have bumped the price up, TRU Canada is asking 16.99$ for this set if memory serves (when they have it in stock) and that is decidedly not worth the price of the contents.

Still I can't fault LEGO for what they were aiming to do when first introducing the LotR Theme. And honestly Shire Frodo is not as easily found as I recall, still with the Polybag out there circulating it isn't too difficult to find it.

Only recommended for completists of the Theme and some-what recommended as a parts pack if you really want more of the new horses.

author: lkb57
title: A Fantastic Start to a Fantastic Theme
review:
Wow! What a great set. Is it small? Yes. Is it fairly simple? Yes. But despite that, in just 83 pieces, TLC managed to put together a perfect rendition of Gandalf's arrival in Hobbiton for Bilbo's 111th birthday.

Parts

Nothing too special here, although the use of a red cobra piece as the dragon firework that Gandalf infamously sets off over Bilbo's party is a clever move and a fantastic addition to the set. Also, I believe this is the first set to feature Lego's new horse model . . . and I'll admit, I'm impressed. Without looking too different from the earlier model, this new horse adds a ton of playability and "pose-ability" for AFOL MOCers.

Minifigures

Gandalf is superb, with a new beard mold and a torso with front and back printing. As far as Frodo goes, I've heard people complain about the simplicity of this model as if that's a bad thing. . . well, I couldn't disagree more! This version of Frodo is supposed to be simple. He is still living a carefree life in the Shire . . . his quest lies ahead of him. In this version of Frodo we get a front-and-back printed torso which captures Frodo's Shire attire perfectly. Both minifigures are superb, IMO.

The build

This is a simple model, so I was surprised to find the build quite enjoyable. I was especially pleased with the construction of the sides of the cart––with just a few pieces and the use of a clever building technique, the designers managed to give the cart an ornate, hand-crafted look that matches the look of the movie cart nicely.

Overall opinion

In short, this is a fantastic set, one that any LOTR/Hobbit collector should jump to get their hands on. You'll only need one, but it's definitely worth the cost.

author: Brickcreator
title: 9469 Gandalf Arrives (In style)
review: 9469 Gandalf arrives is the smallest of The Lord of the Rings boxed sets and is based on the opening scene from The Fellowship of the Ring. It contains 83 pieces and is priced at $12.99 USD. I got mine at an after Christmas sale for $10.31. This 20% savings was what hooked me into purchasing this set. The box contains two bags and a new LEGO horse with moveable back hips. The set contains two minifigures, Gandalf the Grey and Frodo. The build itself is surprisingly interesting for such a small set. The sides of the wagon in particular look incredible. It functions quite well and stays true to the movie. Within the wagon is a letter addressed to Merry, a carrot, and three fireworks, one of which looks suspiciously like a snake. When seated in the front of the wagon, Gandalf does not fit comfortably with his cape on. I would suggest removing the cape before seating him to minimize creasing on the cape. Another thing I would have like to see is the point where the wagon and horse connect should turn. It isn’t very realistic when playing to have no points of motion besides the wheels. There also aren’t any reigns for Gandalf to control his wagon with. He must have a trusting horse! Besides these few flaws, the set is truly a great buy and packs a lot of detail into such a small space.

author: jfriend12
title: Fun little set packed with goodies; captures the spirit of Middle-earth
review:
I rate all LOTR and Hobbit sets based on seven categories, listed below.

Minifigs-8/10-They could have easily just given us Gandalf with this set, so props to Lego for including a special Shire version of Frodo. Both figs are beautifully rendered, especially Frodo, who's green and brown outfit is perfectly designed. Gandalf is generally lovely, although I would have loved if they could have found a way to incorporate his signature long hair, even if it were as an alternative piece to the hat. As of now, he looks like he's bald. Also, I understand the expense of making a new, infrequently used mold, but I really would have liked his staff to be a bit more than a brown stick. That being said his face gets the eyebrows just right, and having a Gandalf minifig is such a thrill to begin with.

Parts-10/10-Lots of useful pieces. We get the new articulated horse, two big wagon wheels, a barrel, a book, a carrot, and a Ninjago snake (used as a firework). That's better than most sets that are twice as large.

Build-10/10-Small sets usually aren't much of a thrill in this department, but this one certainly was. Watching the sides of the wagon come together in the way they do almost felt like assembling an actual horse cart. Nothing frustrating, but never boring, and extra points for achieving that given its size.

Design-9/10-Again, the sides of the wagon are so cleverly developed, with the back piece both creating the angle of the sides and preventing them from collapsing in. I also love the "wooden" posts on either side. They really give the whole thing an appropriately rustic feel. My only issue is that there are small gaps between the sides and bottom, allowing small items to occasionally fall through.

Accuracy/Fan Service-10/10-The model absolutely captures the charm of the scene and looks just like its movie counterpart, and the fireworks are a great detail, especially the big dragon firework. Also, I love that this Frodo gets a different face from the other version. He's less weary and more cheerful here, which is perfect as he has not yet received the ring or been injured by the Witch-King. I love having a more youthful Frodo.

Playability-9/10-No actual play features, but they aren't necessary here, and would likely feel forced and tacked on. Clip-clopping Gandalf around on his cart is great fun, and the multitude of props adds a lot of playability. Gandalf sits a bit off center, which I believe is accurate, although a really wish there was room for Frodo to sit next to him, as he does in the film.

Price-7/10-13$ for 83 pieces is fairly steep, although the license, new minifigs, and horse somewhat explain it. Still, I would have preferred it to be 10$.

THE FINAL TALLY: 63/70 (90%), which puts this great little set at an A-

author: meme100
title: Lego Lord of the Rings Gandalf Arrives
review:
Gandalf Arrives.

Indroduction

The set is a very good and gives you enough to replay the scene from 'the fellowship of the ring' film. The detail is amazing and the characters detail is great.

Gandalf the Grey

Gandalf has lovely detail and his face is great. The staff is represented by a lego stick.

Frodo Baggins

His detail is amazing and the effort on his torso is amazing.

author: Telcontar
title: Small, but Excellent
review:
Even though this is one of the smallest Lord of the Rings (LotR) sets it is still one of the best.  It has tons of playability yest at the same time can be used as a display on that empty piece of furniture.

 

Box/Instructions

The box itself is one of the more flimsy types (which is used for nearly all smaller sets) that requires your thumb to tear open the one side.  This is fine except for the people who try to keep the boxes in top condition.  On the front of the box the entire set takes center stage (of course) with a picturesque background behind which is meant to look like the Shire. 

…

 

Parts

For parts we get mostly tan colors which are so useful (but somewhat rare), plus one of the new horse molds.  In the back of the cart we get several of Gandalf's fireworks (isn't the big, red, "dragon" one a Ninjago snake?).  The two two brown wheels are also extremely nice. 

 

…

 

Minifigures

The two minifgures in this set are both exclusives (to the first wave) which made it a must have being the LotR fanatic that I am.  First I'll start with Gandalf.  His legs are a plain dark grey and his torso is of the same color.  On his torso are several folds in his clothes, even on the back.  Most of the time you can't see them though since his cape and beard are on.  (Speaking of the beard, without it he looks nothing at all like Gandalf :-)  .)

Frodo is sporting his green shirt with suspenders like when we saw him for the first time in the film.  His hair is the same one we get with him in Attack on Weathertop and in Shelob Attacks.  His face however, is exclusive (like his shirt).  One one side we have a happy expresion while on the other side we have a worried look. 

…

 

The build

The build itself is fairly simple, although there are some neat building techniques used in those four tan posts at the corner of the cart. 

…

 

The completed model

When the model is finished it brings back all those memories from the movie (and book) when Gandalf rides into Hobbiton.  The minifigs, build, parts, are all fantastic.  I only have three small complaints.

  • There's not quite enough room for Frodo to sit beside Gandalf.
  • Sometimes the carrot and fireworks fall out the side/bottom of the cart.
  • The price is a little high, perhaps we could have gotten Bilbo, or a Ring?

But it's still one of my favorite sets, especially when you put it beside Bag End. (a Hobbit set) 

…

 

Summary

For being a small set it is fantastic.  It's a great replica from the movie plus it has tons of play opportunities.  The minifgures are great too.  All in all it's one the best LotR sets. 

…

author: BrickBoyC8
title: Gandalf Has to Much Stuff
review:
" Frodo I need your help to destroy the 'One' ring....If the kit had only come with a ring."

Pros

  • Good quality cart with exceptional mini-figs.
  • Great playability.
  • New horse design has more realism than the original.

Cons

  • Items in cart fall out frequently.
  • Impossible to easily sit Gandalf in the cart.
 Overall, this is a great set with amazing playability. I can't wait to get my next LOTR set!

By
BrickBoyC8

author: Arceusrox
title: The first Gandalf of many
review:
Most of the time, I only get smaller sets because my parents don't mind buying them for me. This one I actually really wanted, not only because I'm a huge LotR fan, but it comes with a ton of great parts, and two of the most important characters in the series.

Parts

This set comes with some wonderful parts and accessories, like a book, a carrot, a bag with a letter, and a red snake. It also comes with some different wheels that are bigger than the wheels on other carts.

Minifigures

None of the LotR series could've happened without Gandalf or Frodo! (Or Bilbo, who would've also been nice in this set.) This is the first time we see Gandalf, and at the time it was pretty cool, but now we've got tons of the same one and he's not so special anymore. He still looks nice though, and he has a dark grey wizard hat and cape. He holds a brown staff. Frodo looks great too, and I think this and the polybag are the only sets with him in this outfit. He has a double sided face, one happy and one sort of worried. There's also one of the new brown horses, obviously, who carries the cart.

The build

Like I said before, I always have fun building Lego sets, so I have nothing bad to say about the building experience.

The completed model

It looks adorable when finished, and I really like the placement of the fireworks and bag. It's very hard to get Gandalf to sit on the cart though, especially since there's no place for his cape. 

Overall opinion

For $12, this is definitely a set worth buying, whether you're a Lord of the Rings fan or not. It comes with good pieces, one of the new horses, and two nice minifigs. Pick it up if you see it!

author: alfred_the_buttler
title: Nice little set, lots of cool parts
review:
This is a very nice little set. While it's nothing that is going to blow you away, considering the incredibly small size of this set, it is surprisingly well done and anything more would seem like overkill. 

Minifigures

Oftentimes in these small sets it is the minifigures that either make or break the set, in this case I would say they make the set. While Gandalf may be incredibly common, this one at least includes his hat and cape which to me makes it a much more valuable minifigure than the ones missing one or both of these wardrobe features. 

Frodo on the other hand is unique in that he is dressed in a green shirt suitable for the Shire. While this minifigure does appear in a polybag and is rather easy to obtain, the polybag is a truly pointless set so I would highly recommend picking up this set of you want this minifigure. 

Now technically it's not a minifigure, but the set also comes with a brown horse which of course can be quite useful to add to your LOTR collection as I feel these sets don't usually give you enough horses and this new design is an excellent improvement over my horses from the 80's. The only problem is you don't get a saddle in this set, but those are easy enough to obtain. 

Parts

This is definitely a parts set. Considering how few parts there are in the set, there sure are a lot of cool ones. You of course get the two wheels and the harness. Then you get a cobra which resembles the firework that Merry and Pippin set off. You also get a barrel, a thieves backpack, a carrot, and a book. Certainly not a bad selection of parts. 

The Build

Yes, it's simple, but what do you expect. I still enjoy the way you build the sides of the cart, and while I may have been able to design that myself, the corner posts were rather ingenious using the lamp holders that were so prevalent in Classic Space. The set may not be as intricate as Riddle for the Ring, but it is still fun. 

Overall

Like I said, if you want this alternative Frodo, this is the set to get him in. It's also good if you are looking for a cheap way to get a horse. Otherwise, it isn't anything to special. The playability is rather limited, certainly you wouldn't want to be fighting orcs with this cart. So if Frodo and the horse don't interest you, and you aren't trying to complete your LOTR collection, you may want to save your money for something else. However, if you own the Bag End set, this horse carriage would look great parked in front of it.

author: LC_Bricks
title: Great for what it is
review:
Got mine secondhand, mainly to display it along with my bag end. The minifigures are what you would expect from the set, Frodo and Gandalf are obvious choices but it would have been fun to have another hobbit haswell. There are some nice usage of parts, i especially like the use of the red ninjago snake as a firework. 

Even though its just a wagon, the set has a certain vibe to it that makes it seem more than just a wooden crate on four wheels. It was fun to build even tough it was on the smaller side and it really works great along with my other lotr sets.

if you find it for a good price i defiantly recommend picking it up 

solid 7/10
